Text

THE AWAKENING

[I]0-the rockaway

A green and yellow parrot , which hung in a cage outside the door , kept repeating over and over :

" _ Allez vous - en ! Allez vous - en ! [Sapristi]48-sapristi ! _ That 's all right ! "[49-mr. pontellier]

[He]146-he could speak a little Spanish , and also a language which [nobody]147-nobody understood , unless it was the mocking - bird that hung on the other side of the door , whistling [his]146-he fluty notes out upon the breeze with maddening persistence .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier , unable to read [his]49-mr. pontellier newspaper with any degree of comfort , arose with an expression and an exclamation of disgust .

[He]49-mr. pontellier walked down [the gallery]148-the gallery and across [the narrow " bridges "[49-mr. pontellier] which connected [the Lebrun cottages]150-the lebrun cottages one with the other]149-the narrow " bridges " which connected the lebrun cottages one with the other . [He]49-mr. pontellier had been seated before the door of [the main house]151-the main house . The parrot and the mocking - bird were [the property of [Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun]152-the property of madame lebrun , and [they]152-the property of madame lebrun had the right to make all the noise [they]152-the property of madame lebrun wished . [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier had the privilege of quitting [their]152-the property of madame lebrun society when [they]152-the property of madame lebrun ceased to be entertaining .

[He]49-mr. pontellier stopped before the door of [[his]49-mr. pontellier own cottage]153-his own cottage , which was [the fourth one from [the main building]155-the main building and next to the last]154-the fourth one from the main building and next to the last . Seating [himself]49-mr. pontellier in a wicker rocker which was there , [he]49-mr. pontellier once more applied [himself]49-mr. pontellier to the task of reading the newspaper . The day was Sunday ; the paper was a day old . The Sunday papers had not yet reached [Grand Isle]1-grand isle . [He]49-mr. pontellier was already acquainted with the market reports , and [he]49-mr. pontellier glanced restlessly over the editorials and bits of news which [he]49-mr. pontellier had not had time to read before quitting [New Orleans]2-new orleans the day before .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier wore eye - glasses . [He]49-mr. pontellier was [a man of forty , of medium height and rather slender build]156-a man of forty , of medium height and rather slender build ; [he]49-mr. pontellier stooped a little . [His]49-mr. pontellier hair was brown and straight , parted on one side . [His]49-mr. pontellier beard was neatly and closely trimmed .

Once in a while [he]49-mr. pontellier withdrew [his]49-mr. pontellier glance from the newspaper and looked about [him]49-mr. pontellier . There was more noise than ever over at [the house]157-the house . [The main building]155-the main building was called " [the house]157-the house , "[160-two young girls] to distinguish [it]155-the main building from [the cottages]159-the cottages . The chattering and whistling birds were still at [it]155-the main building . [Two young girls]160-two young girls , [the Farival twins]161-the farival twins , were playing a duet from " Zampa "[160-two young girls] upon the piano . [Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun was bustling in and out , giving orders in a high key to [a yard - boy]162-a yard - boy whenever [she]50-madame lebrun got inside [the house]157-the house , and directions in an equally high voice to [a dining - room servant]164-a dining - room servant whenever [she]50-madame lebrun got outside . [She]50-madame lebrun was [a fresh , pretty woman , clad always in white with elbow sleeves]165-a fresh , pretty woman , clad always in white with elbow sleeves . [Her]50-madame lebrun starched skirts crinkled as [she]50-madame lebrun came and went . Farther down , before [one of [the cottages]159-the cottages]166-one of the cottages , [a lady in black]168-a lady in black was walking demurely up and down , telling [her]168-a lady in black beads . [A good many persons of the _ pension]169-a good many persons of the _ pension _ had gone over to [the _ Ch ni re Caminada]170-the _ ch ni re caminada _ in [Beaudelet]51-beaudelet 's lugger to hear mass . [Some young people]171-some young people were out under the water - oaks playing croquet . [[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier 's two children]172-mr. pontellier 's two children were there sturdy [little fellows of four and five]173-little fellows of four and five . [A quadroon nurse]174-a quadroon nurse followed [them]172-mr. pontellier 's two children about with a faraway , meditative air .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier finally lit a cigar and began to smoke , letting the paper drag idly from [his]49-mr. pontellier hand . [He]49-mr. pontellier fixed [his]49-mr. pontellier gaze upon a white sunshade that was advancing at snail 's pace from [the beach]175-the beach . [He]49-mr. pontellier could see it plainly between the gaunt trunks of the water - oaks and across [the stretch of yellow camomile]176-the stretch of yellow camomile . [The gulf]177-the gulf looked far away , melting hazily into the blue of the horizon . The sunshade continued to approach slowly . Beneath [its]178-its pink - lined shelter were [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife , [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , and [young Robert Lebrun]53-robert . When [they]172-mr. pontellier 's two children reached [the cottage]180-the cottage , [the two]181-the two seated [themselves]181-the two with some appearance of fatigue upon the upper step of [the porch]182-the porch , facing [each other]183-each other , [each]184-each leaning against a supporting post .

" What folly ! to bathe at such an hour in such heat ! "[49-mr. pontellier] exclaimed [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier . [He]49-mr. pontellier [himself]49-mr. pontellier had taken a plunge at daylight . That was why the morning seemed long to [him]49-mr. pontellier .

" [You]179-his wife are burnt beyond recognition , "[49-mr. pontellier] [he]49-mr. pontellier added , looking at [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife as one looks at a valuable piece of personal property which has suffered some damage . [She]179-his wife held up [her]179-his wife hands , strong , shapely hands , and surveyed them critically , drawing up [her]179-his wife fawn sleeves above the wrists . Looking at them reminded [her]179-his wife of [her]179-his wife rings , which [she]179-his wife had given to [[her]179-his wife husband]186-her husband before leaving for [the beach]175-the beach . [She]179-his wife silently reached out to [him]49-mr. pontellier , and [he]49-mr. pontellier , understanding , took the rings from [his]49-mr. pontellier vest pocket and dropped them into [her]179-his wife open palm . [She]179-his wife slipped them upon [her]179-his wife fingers ; then clasping [her]179-his wife knees , [she]179-his wife looked across at [Robert]53-robert and began to laugh . The rings sparkled upon [her]179-his wife fingers . [He]49-mr. pontellier sent back an answering smile .

" What is it ? "[49-mr. pontellier] asked [Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier , looking lazily and amused from one to the other . It was some utter nonsense ; some adventure out there in [the water]188-the water , and [they]189-they both tried to relate it at once . It did not seem half so amusing when told . [They]189-they realized this , and so did [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier . [He]49-mr. pontellier yawned and stretched [himself]49-mr. pontellier . Then [he]49-mr. pontellier got up , saying [he]49-mr. pontellier had half a mind to go over to [[Klein]54-klein 's hotel]190-klein 's hotel and play a game of billiards .

" Come go along , [Lebrun]53-robert , "[49-mr. pontellier] [he]49-mr. pontellier proposed to [Robert]53-robert . But [Robert]53-robert admitted quite frankly that [he]53-robert preferred to stay where [he]53-robert was and talk to [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier .

" Well , send [him]186-her husband about [his]186-her husband business when [he]186-her husband bores [you]52-mrs. pontellier , [Edna]115-edna , "[186-her husband] instructed [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband as [he]186-her husband prepared to leave .

" Here , take the umbrella , "[52-mrs. pontellier] [she]52-mrs. pontellier exclaimed , holding it out to [him]186-her husband . [He]186-her husband accepted the sunshade , and lifting it over [his]186-her husband head descended the steps and walked away .

" Coming back to dinner ? "[179-his wife] [[his]186-her husband wife]179-his wife called after [him]186-her husband . [He]186-her husband halted a moment and shrugged [his]186-her husband shoulders . [He]186-her husband felt in [his]186-her husband vest pocket ; there was a ten - dollar bill there . [He]186-her husband did not know ; perhaps [he]186-her husband would return for the early dinner and perhaps [he]186-her husband would not . It all depended upon the company which [he]186-her husband found over at [Klein 's]54-klein and the size of " the game . "[186-her husband] [He]186-her husband did not say this , but [she]52-mrs. pontellier understood it , and laughed , nodding good - by to [him]186-her husband .

[Both children]193-both children wanted to follow [[their]193-both children father]194-their father when [they]193-both children saw [him]186-her husband starting out . [He]186-her husband kissed [them]193-both children and promised to bring [them]193-both children back bonbons and peanuts .

II

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier 's eyes were quick and bright ; they were a yellowish brown , about the color of [her]52-mrs. pontellier hair . [She]52-mrs. pontellier had a way of turning them swiftly upon an object and holding [them]193-both children there as if lost in some inward maze of contemplation or thought .

[Her]52-mrs. pontellier eyebrows were a shade darker than [her]52-mrs. pontellier hair . They were thick and almost horizontal , emphasizing the depth of [her]52-mrs. pontellier eyes . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was rather handsome than beautiful . [Her]52-mrs. pontellier face was captivating by reason of a certain frankness of expression and a contradictory subtle play of features . [Her]52-mrs. pontellier manner was engaging .

[Robert]53-robert rolled a cigarette . [He]53-robert smoked cigarettes because [he]53-robert could not afford cigars , [he]53-robert said . [He]53-robert had a cigar in [his]53-robert pocket which [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier had presented [him]53-robert with , and [he]53-robert was saving it for [his]53-robert after - dinner smoke .

This seemed quite proper and natural on [his]53-robert part . In coloring [he]53-robert was not unlike [[his]53-robert companion]195-his companion . A clean - shaved face made the resemblance more pronounced than it would otherwise have been . There rested no shadow of care upon [his]53-robert open countenance . [His]53-robert eyes gathered in and reflected the light and languor of the summer day .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier reached over for a palm - leaf fan that lay on [the porch]182-the porch and began to fan [herself]52-mrs. pontellier , while [Robert]53-robert sent between [his]53-robert lips light puffs from [his]53-robert cigarette . [They]197-they chatted incessantly : about the things around [them]197-they ; [their]197-they amusing adventure out in [the water]188-the water it had again assumed its entertaining aspect ; about the wind , the trees , [the people who had gone to [the _ Ch ni re]200-the _ ch ni re]199-the people who had gone to the _ ch ni re ; _ about [the children playing croquet under the oaks]201-the children playing croquet under the oaks , and [the Farival twins , who were now performing the overture to " [The Poet]1724-the poet and [the Peasant]1725-the peasant]1723-the farival twins , who were now performing the overture to " the poet and the peasant . "[1723-the farival twins , who were now performing the overture to " the poet and the peasant]

[Robert]53-robert talked a good deal about [himself]53-robert . [He]53-robert was very young , and did not know any better . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier talked a little about [herself]52-mrs. pontellier for the same reason . [Each]202-each was interested in what [the other]203-the other said . [Robert]53-robert spoke of [his]53-robert intention to go to [Mexico]4-mexico in the autumn , where fortune awaited [him]53-robert . [He]53-robert was always intending to go to [Mexico]4-mexico , but some way never got [there]204-there . Meanwhile [he]53-robert held on to [his]53-robert modest position in [a mercantile house in [New Orleans]2-new orleans , where an equal familiarity with English , French and Spanish]205-a mercantile house in new orleans , where an equal familiarity with english , french and spanish gave [him]53-robert no small value as [a clerk]206-a clerk and [correspondent]207-correspondent .

[He]53-robert was spending [his]53-robert summer vacation , as [he]53-robert always did , with [[his]53-robert mother]208-his mother at [Grand Isle]1-grand isle . In former times , before [Robert]53-robert could remember , " [the house]157-the house "[53-robert] had been [a summer luxury of [the Lebruns]56-the lebruns]209-a summer luxury of the lebruns . Now , flanked by [its]209-a summer luxury of the lebruns [dozen or more cottages]210-dozen or more cottages , which were always filled with [exclusive visitors from [the " _ Quartier Fran ais _]1728-the " _ quartier fran ais _]1727-exclusive visitors from the " _ quartier fran ais _ , "[1727-exclusive visitors from the " _ quartier fran ais _] it enabled [Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun to maintain the easy and comfortable existence which appeared to be [her]50-madame lebrun birthright .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier talked about [[[her]52-mrs. pontellier father]211-her father 's Mississippi plantation]212-her father 's mississippi plantation and [[her]52-mrs. pontellier girlhood home in [the old Kentucky blue - grass country]214-the old kentucky blue - grass country]213-her girlhood home in the old kentucky blue - grass country . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was [an American woman , with a small infusion of French which seemed to have been lost in dilution]215-an american woman , with a small infusion of french which seemed to have been lost in dilution . [She]52-mrs. pontellier read a letter from [[her]52-mrs. pontellier sister , who was away in [the East]217-the east , and who had engaged [herself]216-her sister , who was away in the east , and who had engaged herself to be married to be married]216-her sister , who was away in the east , and who had engaged herself to be married . [Robert]53-robert was interested , and wanted to know what manner of girls [the sisters]218-the sisters were , what [the father]219-the father was like , and how long [the mother]220-the mother had been dead .

When [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier folded the letter it was time for [her]52-mrs. pontellier to dress for the early dinner .

" [I]52-mrs. pontellier see [L]57-l once is n't coming back , "[52-mrs. pontellier] [she]52-mrs. pontellier said , with a glance in the direction whence [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband had disappeared . [Robert]53-robert supposed [he]186-her husband was not , as there were [a good many [New Orleans club men over at [Klein 's]54-klein]223-new orleans club men over at klein 's]222-a good many new orleans club men over at klein 's .

When [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier left [him]186-her husband to enter [[her]52-mrs. pontellier room]224-her room , [the young man]225-the young man descended the steps and strolled over toward [the croquet players]226-the croquet players , where , during the half - hour before dinner , [he]225-the young man amused [himself]225-the young man with [the little Pontellier children , who were very fond of [him]225-the young man]227-the little pontellier children , who were very fond of him .

III

It was eleven o'clock that night when [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier returned from [[Klein]54-klein 's hotel]190-klein 's hotel . [He]49-mr. pontellier was in an excellent humor , in high spirits , and very talkative . [His]49-mr. pontellier entrance awoke [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife , who was in bed and fast asleep when [he]49-mr. pontellier came in]229-his wife , who was in bed and fast asleep when he came in . [He]49-mr. pontellier talked to [her]229-his wife , who was in bed and fast asleep when he came in while [he]49-mr. pontellier undressed , telling [her]229-his wife , who was in bed and fast asleep when he came in anecdotes and bits of news and gossip that [he]49-mr. pontellier had gathered during the day . From [his]49-mr. pontellier trousers pockets [he]49-mr. pontellier took a fistful of crumpled bank notes and a good deal of silver coin , which [he]49-mr. pontellier piled on the bureau indiscriminately with keys , knife , handkerchief , and whatever else happened to be in [his]49-mr. pontellier pockets . [She]229-his wife , who was in bed and fast asleep when he came in was overcome with sleep , and answered [him]49-mr. pontellier with little half utterances .

[He]49-mr. pontellier thought it very discouraging that [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife , who was the sole object of [his]49-mr. pontellier existence , evinced so little interest in things which concerned [him]49-mr. pontellier , and valued so little [his]49-mr. pontellier conversation .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier had forgotten the bonbons and peanuts for [the boys]231-the boys . Notwithstanding [he]49-mr. pontellier loved [them]231-the boys very much , and went into [the adjoining room]232-the adjoining room where [they]231-the boys slept to take a look at [them]231-the boys and make sure that [they]231-the boys were resting comfortably . The result of [his]49-mr. pontellier investigation was far from satisfactory . [He]49-mr. pontellier turned and shifted [the youngsters]233-the youngsters about in bed . [One of [them]233-the youngsters]234-one of them began to kick and talk about a basket full of crabs .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier returned to [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife with the information that [Raoul]58-raoul had a high fever and needed looking after . Then [he]49-mr. pontellier lit a cigar and went and sat near the open door to smoke it .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was quite sure [Raoul]58-raoul had no fever . [He]58-raoul had gone to bed perfectly well , [she]52-mrs. pontellier said , and nothing had ailed [him]58-raoul all day . [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier was too well acquainted with fever symptoms to be mistaken . [He]49-mr. pontellier assured [her]52-mrs. pontellier [the child]236-the child was consuming at that moment in [the next room]237-the next room .

[He]49-mr. pontellier reproached [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife with [her]52-mrs. pontellier inattention , [her]52-mrs. pontellier habitual neglect of [the children]239-the children . If it was not [[a mother]240-a mother 's place to look after [children]242-children]241-a mother 's place to look after children , whose on earth was it ? [He]49-mr. pontellier [himself]49-mr. pontellier had [his]49-mr. pontellier hands full with [his]49-mr. pontellier brokerage business . [He]49-mr. pontellier could not be in two places at once ; making a living for [[his]49-mr. pontellier family]243-his family on [the street]244-the street , and staying at [home]245-home to see that no harm befell [them]243-his family . [He]49-mr. pontellier talked in a monotonous , insistent way .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier sprang out of bed and went into [the next room]237-the next room . [She]52-mrs. pontellier soon came back and sat on the edge of the bed , leaning [her]52-mrs. pontellier head down on the pillow . [She]52-mrs. pontellier said nothing , and refused to answer [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband when [he]186-her husband questioned [her]52-mrs. pontellier . When [his]49-mr. pontellier cigar was smoked out [he]49-mr. pontellier went to bed , and in half a minute [he]49-mr. pontellier was fast asleep .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was by that time thoroughly awake . [She]52-mrs. pontellier began to cry a little , and wiped [her]52-mrs. pontellier eyes on the sleeve of [her]52-mrs. pontellier _ peignoir _ . Blowing out the candle , which [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband had left burning , [she]52-mrs. pontellier slipped [her]52-mrs. pontellier bare feet into a pair of satin _ mules _ at the foot of the bed and went out on [the porch]182-the porch , where [she]52-mrs. pontellier sat down in the wicker chair and began to rock gently to and fro .

It was then past midnight . [The cottages]159-the cottages were all dark . A single faint light gleamed out from [the hallway of [the house]157-the house]251-the hallway of the house . There was no sound abroad except the hooting of an old owl in the top of a water - oak , and the everlasting voice of [the sea]253-the sea , that was not uplifted at that soft hour . It broke like a mournful lullaby upon the night .

The tears came so fast to [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier 's eyes that the damp sleeve of [her]52-mrs. pontellier _ peignoir _ no longer served to dry them . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was holding the back of [her]52-mrs. pontellier chair with one hand ; [her]52-mrs. pontellier loose sleeve had slipped almost to the shoulder of [her]52-mrs. pontellier uplifted arm . Turning , [she]52-mrs. pontellier thrust [her]52-mrs. pontellier face , steaming and wet , into the bend of [her]52-mrs. pontellier arm , and [she]52-mrs. pontellier went on crying there , not caring any longer to dry [her]52-mrs. pontellier face , [her]52-mrs. pontellier eyes , [her]52-mrs. pontellier arms . [She]52-mrs. pontellier could not have told why [she]52-mrs. pontellier was crying . Such experiences as the foregoing were not uncommon in [her]52-mrs. pontellier married life . [They]254-they seemed never before to have weighed much against the abundance of [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband 's kindness and a uniform devotion which had come to be tacit and self - understood .

An indescribable oppression , which seemed to generate in some unfamiliar part of [her]52-mrs. pontellier consciousness , filled [her]52-mrs. pontellier whole being with a vague anguish . It was like a shadow , like a mist passing across [her]52-mrs. pontellier soul 's summer day . It was strange and unfamiliar ; it was a mood . [She]52-mrs. pontellier did not sit there inwardly upbraiding [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband , lamenting at Fate , which had directed [her]52-mrs. pontellier footsteps to the path which [they]257-they had taken . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was just having a good cry all to [herself]52-mrs. pontellier . The mosquitoes made merry over [her]52-mrs. pontellier , biting [her]52-mrs. pontellier firm , round arms and nipping at [her]52-mrs. pontellier bare insteps .

The little stinging , buzzing imps succeeded in dispelling a mood which might have held [her]52-mrs. pontellier there in the darkness half a night longer .

The following morning [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier was up in good time to take [the rockaway]258-the rockaway which was to convey [him]49-mr. pontellier to [the steamer]259-the steamer at [the wharf]260-the wharf . [He]49-mr. pontellier was returning to [the city]261-the city to [[his]49-mr. pontellier business]262-his business , and [they]257-they would not see [him]49-mr. pontellier again at [the Island]263-the island till the coming Saturday . [He]49-mr. pontellier had regained [his]49-mr. pontellier composure , which seemed to have been somewhat impaired the night before . [He]49-mr. pontellier was eager to be gone , as [he]49-mr. pontellier looked forward to a lively week in [Carondelet Street]5-carondelet street .

[Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier gave [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife half of the money which [he]49-mr. pontellier had brought away from [[Klein]54-klein 's hotel]190-klein 's hotel the evening before . [She]179-his wife liked money as well as [most women]266-most women , and accepted it with no little satisfaction .

" It will buy a handsome wedding present for [Sister Janet]59-janet ! "[179-his wife] [she]179-his wife exclaimed , smoothing out the bills as [she]179-his wife counted them one by one .

" Oh ! [we]1729-we 'll treat [Sister Janet]59-janet better than that , [[my]49-mr. pontellier dear]1730-my dear , "[49-mr. pontellier] [he]49-mr. pontellier laughed , as [he]49-mr. pontellier prepared to kiss [her]179-his wife good - by .

[The boys]231-the boys were tumbling about , clinging to [his]49-mr. pontellier legs , imploring that numerous things be brought back to [them]231-the boys . [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier was a great favorite , and [ladies]268-ladies , [men]269-men , [children]242-children , even [nurses]271-nurses , were always on hand to say good - by to [him]49-mr. pontellier . [[His]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife stood smiling and waving , [the boys]231-the boys shouting , as [he]49-mr. pontellier disappeared in [the old rockaway]274-the old rockaway down [the sandy road]275-the sandy road .

A few days later a box arrived for [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier from [New Orleans]2-new orleans . It was from [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband . It was filled with _ friandises _ , with luscious and toothsome bits the finest of fruits , _ pat s _ , a rare bottle or two , delicious syrups , and bonbons in abundance .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was always very generous with the contents of such a box ; [she]52-mrs. pontellier was quite used to receiving them when away from [home]245-home . The _ pat s _ and fruit were brought to [the dining - room]278-the dining - room ; the bonbons were passed around . And [the ladies]279-the ladies , selecting with dainty and discriminating fingers and a little greedily , all declared that [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier was [the best husband in [the world]281-the world]280-the best husband in the world . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was forced to admit that [she]52-mrs. pontellier knew of none better .

[IV]60-iv

It would have been a difficult matter for [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier to define to [his]49-mr. pontellier own satisfaction or [any one else]282-any one else 's wherein [[his]49-mr. pontellier wife]179-his wife failed in [her]179-his wife duty toward [[their]284-their children]285-their children . It was something which [he]49-mr. pontellier felt rather than perceived , and [he]49-mr. pontellier never voiced the feeling without subsequent regret and ample atonement .

If [one of [the little Pontellier boys]287-the little pontellier boys]286-one of the little pontellier boys took a tumble whilst at play , [he]286-one of the little pontellier boys was not apt to rush crying to [[his]286-one of the little pontellier boys mother]208-his mother 's arms for comfort ; [he]286-one of the little pontellier boys would more likely pick [himself]286-one of the little pontellier boys up , wipe the water out of [his]286-one of the little pontellier boys eyes and the sand out of [his]286-one of the little pontellier boys mouth , and go on playing . [Tots]61-tots as [they]61-tots were , [they]61-tots pulled together and stood [their]61-tots ground in childish battles with doubled fists and uplifted voices , which usually prevailed against [the other mother - tots]289-the other mother - tots . [The quadroon nurse]290-the quadroon nurse was looked upon as a huge encumbrance , only good to button up waists and panties and to brush and part hair ; since it seemed to be a law of society that hair must be parted and brushed .

In short , [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was not [a mother - woman]291-a mother - woman . [The mother - women]292-the mother - women seemed to prevail that summer at [Grand Isle]1-grand isle . It was easy to know [them]292-the mother - women , fluttering about with extended , protecting wings when any harm , real or imaginary , threatened [their]292-the mother - women precious brood . [They]292-the mother - women were [women who idolized [[their]292-the mother - women children]285-their children , worshiped [[their]292-the mother - women husbands]295-their husbands , and esteemed it a holy privilege to efface [themselves]292-the mother - women as [individuals and grow wings as ministering angels]296-individuals and grow wings as ministering angels .

[Many of [them]292-the mother - women]297-many of them were delicious in the role ; one of [them]292-the mother - women was the embodiment of every womanly grace and charm . If [[her]52-mrs. pontellier husband]186-her husband]293-women who idolized their children , worshiped their husbands , and esteemed it a holy privilege to efface themselves as individuals and grow wings as ministering angels . many of them were delicious in the role ; one of them was the embodiment of every womanly grace and charm . if her husband did not adore [her]52-mrs. pontellier , [he]186-her husband was [a brute , deserving of death by slow torture]299-a brute , deserving of death by slow torture . [Her]52-mrs. pontellier name was Ad [le Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle . There are no words to describe [her]52-mrs. pontellier save the old ones that have served so often to picture [the bygone heroine of romance]300-the bygone heroine of romance and [the fair lady of [our]302-our dreams]301-the fair lady of our dreams . There was nothing subtle or hidden about [her]52-mrs. pontellier charms ; [her]52-mrs. pontellier beauty was all there , flaming and apparent : the spun - gold hair that comb nor confining pin could restrain ; the blue eyes that were like nothing but sapphires ; two lips that pouted , that were so red [one]303-one could only think of cherries or some other delicious crimson fruit in looking at them . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was growing a little stout , but it did not seem to detract an iota from the grace of every step , pose , gesture . [One]303-one would not have wanted [her]52-mrs. pontellier white neck a mite less full or [her]52-mrs. pontellier beautiful arms more slender . Never were hands more exquisite than [hers]52-mrs. pontellier , and it was a joy to look at them when [she]52-mrs. pontellier threaded [her]52-mrs. pontellier needle or adjusted [her]52-mrs. pontellier gold thimble to [her]52-mrs. pontellier taper middle finger as [she]52-mrs. pontellier sewed away on the little night - drawers or fashioned a bodice or a bib .

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle was very fond of [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , and often [she]52-mrs. pontellier took [her]52-mrs. pontellier sewing and went over to sit with [her]52-mrs. pontellier in the afternoons . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was sitting there the afternoon of the day the box arrived from [New Orleans]2-new orleans . [She]52-mrs. pontellier had possession of the rocker , and [she]52-mrs. pontellier was busily engaged in sewing upon a diminutive pair of night - drawers .

[She]52-mrs. pontellier had brought the pattern of the drawers for [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier to cut out a marvel of construction , fashioned to enclose [a baby]305-a baby 's body so effectually that only two small eyes might look out from the garment , like an Eskimo 's . They were designed for winter wear , when treacherous drafts came down chimneys and insidious currents of deadly cold found their way through key - holes .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier 's mind was quite at rest concerning the present material needs of [[her]52-mrs. pontellier children]306-her children , and [she]52-mrs. pontellier could not see the use of anticipating and making winter night garments the subject of [her]52-mrs. pontellier summer meditations . But [she]52-mrs. pontellier did not want to appear unamiable and uninterested , so [she]52-mrs. pontellier had brought forth newspapers , which [she]52-mrs. pontellier spread upon the floor of [the gallery]148-the gallery , and under [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle 's directions [she]52-mrs. pontellier had cut a pattern of the impervious garment .

[Robert]53-robert was [there]204-there , seated as [he]53-robert had been the Sunday before , and [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier also occupied [her]52-mrs. pontellier former position on the upper step , leaning listlessly against the post . Beside [her]52-mrs. pontellier was a box of bonbons , which [she]52-mrs. pontellier held out at intervals to [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle .

[That lady]309-that lady seemed at a loss to make a selection , but finally settled upon a stick of nougat , wondering if it were not too rich ; whether it could possibly hurt [her]52-mrs. pontellier . [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle had been married seven years . About every two years [she]62-madame ratignolle had [a baby]305-a baby . At that time [she]62-madame ratignolle had [three babies]311-three babies , and was beginning to think of a fourth one . [She]62-madame ratignolle was always talking about [her]62-madame ratignolle " condition . "[62-madame ratignolle] [Her]62-madame ratignolle " condition "[62-madame ratignolle] was in no way apparent , and [no one]312-no one would have known a thing about it but for [her]62-madame ratignolle persistence in making it the subject of conversation .

[Robert]53-robert started to reassure [her]62-madame ratignolle , asserting that [he]53-robert had known [a lady who had subsisted upon nougat during the entire but seeing the color mount into]313-a lady who had subsisted upon nougat during the entire but seeing the color mount into [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier 's face [he]53-robert checked [himself]53-robert and changed the subject .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , though [she]52-mrs. pontellier had married [a Creole]314-a creole , was not thoroughly at [home]245-home in [the society of [Creoles]63-creoles]316-the society of creoles ; never before had [she]52-mrs. pontellier been thrown so intimately among [them]63-creoles . There were only [Creoles]317-creoles that summer at [Lebrun 's]53-robert . [They]318-their all knew [each other]183-each other , and felt like [one large family , among whom existed the most amicable relations]320-one large family , among whom existed the most amicable relations . A characteristic which distinguished [them]318-their and which impressed [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier most forcibly was [their]318-their entire absence of prudery . [Their]318-their freedom of expression was at first incomprehensible to [her]52-mrs. pontellier , though [she]52-mrs. pontellier had no difficulty in reconciling it with a lofty chastity which in [the Creole woman]321-the creole woman seems to be inborn and unmistakable .

Never would [Edna Pontellier]115-edna forget the shock with which [she]115-edna heard [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle relating to [old Monsieur Farival]64-old monsieur farival the harrowing story of one of [her]62-madame ratignolle _ accouchements _ , withholding no intimate detail . [She]115-edna was growing accustomed to like shocks , but [she]115-edna could not keep the mounting color back from [her]115-edna cheeks . [Oftener]65-oftener than once [her]115-edna coming had interrupted the droll story with which [Robert]53-robert was entertaining [some amused group of [married women]323-married women]322-some amused group of married women .

A book had gone the rounds of the _ pension _ . When it came [her]115-edna turn to read it , [she]115-edna did so with profound astonishment . [She]115-edna felt moved to read the book in secret and solitude , though none of [the others]324-the others had done so , to hide it from view at the sound of approaching footsteps . It was openly criticised and freely discussed at table . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier gave over being astonished , and concluded that wonders would never cease .

[V]66-v

[They]325-they formed [a congenial group]326-a congenial group sitting there that summer afternoon [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle sewing away , often stopping to relate a story or incident with much expressive gesture of [her]62-madame ratignolle perfect hands ; [Robert]53-robert and [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier sitting idle , exchanging occasional words , glances or smiles which indicated a certain advanced stage of intimacy and _ camaraderie _ .

[He]53-robert had lived in [her]115-edna shadow during the past month . [No one]312-no one thought anything of it . Many had predicted that [Robert]53-robert would devote [himself]53-robert to [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier when [he]53-robert arrived . Since the age of fifteen , which was eleven years before , [Robert]53-robert each summer at [Grand Isle]1-grand isle had constituted [himself]53-robert [the devoted attendant of some fair dame or damsel]328-the devoted attendant of some fair dame or damsel . Sometimes it was [a young girl]329-a young girl , again [a widow]330-a widow ; but as often as not it was [some interesting married woman]331-some interesting married woman .

For two consecutive seasons [he]53-robert lived in the sunlight of [Mademoiselle Duvigne]67-mademoiselle duvigne 's presence . But [she]67-mademoiselle duvigne died between summers ; then [Robert]53-robert posed as an inconsolable , prostrating [himself]53-robert at the feet of [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle for whatever crumbs of sympathy and comfort [she]62-madame ratignolle might be pleased to vouchsafe .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier liked to sit and gaze at [[her]52-mrs. pontellier fair companion]332-her fair companion as [she]52-mrs. pontellier might look upon [a faultless Madonna]333-a faultless madonna .

" Could [any one]1731-any one fathom the cruelty beneath that fair exterior ? "[53-robert] murmured [Robert]53-robert . " [She]62-madame ratignolle knew that [I]53-robert adored [her]62-madame ratignolle once , and [she]62-madame ratignolle let [me]53-robert adore [her]62-madame ratignolle . " _ Par exemple ! _ [I]335-i never had to ask . [You]53-robert were always there under [my]335-i feet , like a troublesome cat . "[335-i]

" Perhaps [I]334-i feared to make [Alphonse]68-alphonse jealous , "[334-i] [she]334-i interjoined , with excessive na vet . That made [them]335-i all laugh . The right hand jealous of the left ! The heart jealous of the soul ! But for that matter , [the Creole husband]336-the creole husband is never jealous ; with [him]336-the creole husband the gangrene passion is one which has become dwarfed by disuse .

Meanwhile [Robert]53-robert , addressing [Mrs Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , continued to tell of [his]53-robert one time hopeless passion for [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle ; of sleepless nights , of consuming flames till [the very sea]337-the very sea sizzled when [he]53-robert took [his]53-robert daily plunge . While [the lady at the needle]338-the lady at the needle kept up a little running , contemptuous comment :

" _ Blagueur farceur gros b te , va ! _ "[338-the lady at the needle]

[He]53-robert never assumed this seriocomic tone when alone with [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier . [She]52-mrs. pontellier never knew precisely what to make of it ; at that moment it was impossible for [her]52-mrs. pontellier to guess how much of it was jest and what proportion was earnest . It was understood that [he]53-robert had often spoken words of love to [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle , without any thought of being taken seriously . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was glad [he]53-robert had not assumed a similar role toward [herself]52-mrs. pontellier . It would have been unacceptable and annoying .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier had brought [her]52-mrs. pontellier sketching materials , which [she]52-mrs. pontellier sometimes dabbled with in an unprofessional way . [She]52-mrs. pontellier liked the dabbling . [She]52-mrs. pontellier felt in it satisfaction of a kind which no other employment afforded [her]52-mrs. pontellier .

[She]52-mrs. pontellier had long wished to try [herself]52-mrs. pontellier on [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle . Never had [that lady]309-that lady seemed a more tempting subject than at that moment , seated there like [some sensuous Madonna]340-some sensuous madonna , with the gleam of the fading day enriching [her]309-that lady splendid color .

[Robert]53-robert crossed over and seated [himself]53-robert upon the step below [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , that [he]53-robert might watch [her]52-mrs. pontellier work . [She]52-mrs. pontellier handled [her]52-mrs. pontellier brushes with a certain ease and freedom which came , not from long and close acquaintance with [them]341-them , but from a natural aptitude . [Robert]53-robert followed [her]52-mrs. pontellier work with close attention , giving forth little ejaculatory expressions of appreciation in French , which [he]53-robert addressed to [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle .

" _ Mais ce n'est pas mal ! Elle s'y connait , elle a de la force , oui . _ "[53-robert]

During [his]53-robert oblivious attention [he]53-robert once quietly rested [his]53-robert head against [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier 's arm . As gently [she]52-mrs. pontellier repulsed [him]53-robert . Once again [he]53-robert repeated the offense . [She]52-mrs. pontellier could not but believe it to be thoughtlessness on [his]53-robert part ; yet that was no reason [she]52-mrs. pontellier should submit to it . [She]52-mrs. pontellier did not remonstrate , except again to repulse [him]53-robert quietly but firmly . [He]53-robert offered no apology . The picture completed bore no resemblance to [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle . [She]52-mrs. pontellier was greatly disappointed to find that it did not look like [her]62-madame ratignolle . But it was a fair enough piece of work , and in many respects satisfying .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier evidently did not think so . After surveying the sketch critically [she]52-mrs. pontellier drew a broad smudge of paint across its surface , and crumpled the paper between [her]52-mrs. pontellier hands .

[The youngsters]233-the youngsters came tumbling up the steps , the quadroon following at the respectful distance which [they]233-the youngsters required [her]52-mrs. pontellier to observe . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier made [them]233-the youngsters carry [her]52-mrs. pontellier paints and things into [the house]157-the house . [She]52-mrs. pontellier sought to detain [them]233-the youngsters for a little talk and some pleasantry . But [they]233-the youngsters were greatly in earnest . [They]233-the youngsters had only come to investigate the contents of the bonbon box . [They]233-the youngsters accepted without murmuring what [she]52-mrs. pontellier chose to give [them]233-the youngsters , each holding out two chubby hands scoop - like , in the vain hope that they might be filled ; and then away [they]233-the youngsters went .

The sun was low in the west , and the breeze soft and languorous that came up from the south , charged with the seductive odor of [the sea]253-the sea . [Children]242-children freshly befurbelowed , were gathering for [their]242-children games under the oaks . [Their]242-children voices were high and penetrating .

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle folded [her]62-madame ratignolle sewing , placing thimble , scissors , and thread all neatly together in the roll , which [she]62-madame ratignolle pinned securely . [She]62-madame ratignolle complained of faintness . [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier flew for the cologne water and a fan . [She]52-mrs. pontellier bathed [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle 's face with cologne , while [Robert]53-robert plied the fan with unnecessary vigor .

The spell was soon over , and [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier could not help wondering if there were not a little imagination responsible for its origin , for the rose tint had never faded from [[her]52-mrs. pontellier friend]346-her friend 's face .

[She]52-mrs. pontellier stood watching [the fair woman]347-the fair woman walk down the long line of galleries with the grace and majesty which [queens]348-queens are sometimes supposed to possess . [[Her]52-mrs. pontellier little ones]349-her little ones ran to meet [her]52-mrs. pontellier . Two of [them]349-her little ones clung about [her]52-mrs. pontellier white skirts , the third [she]52-mrs. pontellier took from [its nurse]350-its nurse and with a thousand endearments bore it along in [her]52-mrs. pontellier own fond , encircling arms . Though , as [everybody]351-everybody well knew , [the doctor]352-the doctor had forbidden [her]52-mrs. pontellier to lift so much as a pin !

" Are [you]52-mrs. pontellier going bathing ? "[53-robert] asked [[Robert]53-robert of [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier]353-robert of mrs. pontellier . It was not so much a question as a reminder .

" Oh , no , "[52-mrs. pontellier] [she]52-mrs. pontellier answered , with a tone of indecision . " [I]52-mrs. pontellier 'm tired ; [I]52-mrs. pontellier think not . "[52-mrs. pontellier] [Her]52-mrs. pontellier glance wandered from [his]53-robert face away toward [the Gulf]177-the gulf , whose sonorous murmur reached [her]52-mrs. pontellier like a loving but imperative entreaty .

" Oh , come ! "[53-robert] [he]53-robert insisted . " [You]52-mrs. pontellier must n't miss [your]52-mrs. pontellier bath . Come on . The water must be delicious ; it will not hurt [you]52-mrs. pontellier . Come . "[53-robert]

[He]53-robert reached up for [her]52-mrs. pontellier big , rough straw hat that hung on a peg outside the door , and put it on [her]52-mrs. pontellier head . [They]355-they descended the steps , and walked away together toward [the beach]175-the beach . The sun was low in the west and the breeze was soft and warm .

[VI

Edna Pontellier]115-edna could not have told why , wishing to go to [the beach]175-the beach with [Robert]53-robert , [she]115-edna should in the first place have declined , and in the second place have followed in obedience to one of the two contradictory impulses which impelled [her]115-edna .

A certain light was beginning to dawn dimly within [her]115-edna , the light which , showing the way , forbids it .

At that early period it served but to bewilder [her]115-edna . It moved [her]115-edna to dreams , to thoughtfulness , to the shadowy anguish which had overcome [her]115-edna the midnight when [she]115-edna had abandoned [herself]115-edna to tears .

In short , [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was beginning to realize [her]115-edna position in [the universe]358-the universe as [a human being]359-a human being , and to recognize [her]115-edna relations as [an individual to the world within and about [her]115-edna]360-an individual to the world within and about her . This may seem like a ponderous weight of wisdom to descend upon the soul of [a young woman of twenty - eight]361-a young woman of twenty - eight perhaps more wisdom than [the Holy Ghost]362-the holy ghost is usually pleased to vouchsafe to [any woman]363-any woman .

But the beginning of things , of [a world]364-a world especially , is necessarily vague , tangled , chaotic , and exceedingly disturbing . How few of [us]365-us ever emerge from such beginning ! How many souls perish in its tumult !

The voice of [the sea]253-the sea is seductive ; never ceasing , whispering , clamoring , murmuring , inviting the soul to wander for a spell in abysses of solitude ; to lose itself in mazes of inward contemplation .

The voice of [the sea]253-the sea speaks to the soul . The touch of [the sea]253-the sea is sensuous , enfolding the body in its soft , close embrace .

[VII

Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier was not [a woman given to confidences]369-a woman given to confidences , a characteristic hitherto contrary to [her]115-edna nature . Even as [a child]370-a child [she]115-edna had lived [her]115-edna own small life all within [herself]115-edna . At a very early period [she]115-edna had apprehended instinctively the dual life that outward existence which conforms , the inward life which questions .

That summer at [Grand Isle]1-grand isle [she]115-edna began to loosen a little the mantle of reserve that had always enveloped [her]115-edna . There may have been there must have been influences , both subtle and apparent , working in [their]371-their several ways to induce [her]115-edna to do this ; but the most obvious was the influence of [Ad le Ratignolle]69-ad le . The excessive physical charm of [the Creole]372-the creole had first attracted [her]115-edna , for [Edna]115-edna had a sensuous susceptibility to beauty . Then the candor of [the woman]373-the woman 's whole existence , which [every one]374-every one might read , and which formed so striking a contrast to [her]115-edna own habitual reserve this might have furnished a link . Who can tell what metals [the gods]375-the gods use in forging the subtle bond which [we]376-we call sympathy , which [we]376-we might as well call love .

[The two women]377-the two women went away one morning to [the beach]175-the beach together , arm in arm , under the huge white sunshade . [Edna]115-edna had prevailed upon [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle to leave [the children]239-the children behind , though [she]62-madame ratignolle could not induce [her]62-madame ratignolle to relinquish a diminutive roll of needlework , which Ad le begged to be allowed to slip into the depths of [her]62-madame ratignolle pocket . In some unaccountable way [they]239-the children had escaped from [Robert]53-robert .

The walk to [the beach]175-the beach was no inconsiderable one , consisting as [it]381-it did of [a long , sandy path]382-a long , sandy path , upon which a sporadic and tangled growth that bordered [it]381-it on either side made frequent and unexpected inroads . There were [acres of yellow camomile]383-acres of yellow camomile reaching out on either hand . Further away still , [vegetable gardens]384-vegetable gardens abounded , with frequent [small plantations of orange or lemon trees intervening]385-small plantations of orange or lemon trees intervening . The dark green clusters glistened from afar in the sun .

[The women]386-the women were both of goodly height , [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle possessing [the more feminine and matronly figure]387-the more feminine and matronly figure . The charm of [Edna Pontellier]115-edna 's physique stole insensibly upon [you]388-you . The lines of [her]115-edna body were long , clean and symmetrical ; it was a body which occasionally fell into splendid poses ; there was no suggestion of the trim , stereotyped fashion - plate about it . [A casual and indiscriminating observer]389-a casual and indiscriminating observer , in passing , might not cast a second glance upon [the figure]390-the figure . But with more feeling and discernment [he]389-a casual and indiscriminating observer would have recognized the noble beauty of its modeling , and the graceful severity of poise and movement , which made [Edna Pontellier]115-edna different from [the crowd]391-the crowd .

[She]115-edna wore a cool muslin that morning white , with a waving vertical line of brown running through it ; also a white linen collar and the big straw hat which [she]115-edna had taken from the peg outside the door . The hat rested any way on [her]115-edna yellow - brown hair , that waved a little , was heavy , and clung close to [her]115-edna head .

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle , more careful of [her]62-madame ratignolle complexion , had twined a gauze veil about [her]62-madame ratignolle head . [She]62-madame ratignolle wore dogskin gloves , with gauntlets that protected [her]62-madame ratignolle wrists . [She]62-madame ratignolle was dressed in pure white , with a fluffiness of ruffles that became [her]62-madame ratignolle . The draperies and fluttering things which [she]62-madame ratignolle wore suited [her]62-madame ratignolle rich , luxuriant beauty as a greater severity of line could not have done .

There were [a number of bath - houses along [the beach]175-the beach]392-a number of bath - houses along the beach , of rough but solid construction , built with [small , protecting galleries facing [the water]188-the water]394-small , protecting galleries facing the water . [Each house]396-each house consisted of [two compartments]397-two compartments , and [[each family]398-each family at [Lebrun 's]53-robert]399-each family at lebrun 's possessed [a compartment for [itself]399-each family at lebrun 's , fitted out with all the essential paraphernalia of the bath and whatever other conveniences [the owners]401-the owners might desire]400-a compartment for itself , fitted out with all the essential paraphernalia of the bath and whatever other conveniences the owners might desire . [The two women]377-the two women had no intention of bathing ; [they]377-the two women had just strolled down to [the beach]175-the beach for a walk and to be alone and near [the water]188-the water . [The Pontellier]115-edna and [[Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle compartments]405-ratignolle compartments adjoined [one another under the same roof]406-one another under the same roof .

[Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier had brought down [her]52-mrs. pontellier key through force of habit . Unlocking the door of [[her]52-mrs. pontellier bath - room]407-her bath - room [she]52-mrs. pontellier went inside , and soon emerged , bringing a rug , which [she]52-mrs. pontellier spread upon the floor of [the gallery]148-the gallery , and two huge hair pillows covered with crash , which [she]52-mrs. pontellier placed against the front of [the building]409-the building .

[The two]181-the two seated [themselves]181-the two there in the shade of [the porch]182-the porch , side by side , with [their]181-the two backs against the pillows and [their]181-the two feet extended . [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle removed [her]62-madame ratignolle veil , wiped [her]62-madame ratignolle face with a rather delicate handkerchief , and fanned [herself]62-madame ratignolle with the fan which [she]62-madame ratignolle always carried suspended somewhere about [her]62-madame ratignolle person by a long , narrow ribbon . [Edna]115-edna removed [her]115-edna collar and opened [her]115-edna dress at the throat . [She]115-edna took the fan from [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle and began to fan both [herself]115-edna and [[her]115-edna companion]412-her companion . It was very warm , and for a while [they]181-the two did nothing but exchange remarks about the heat , the sun , the glare . But there was a breeze blowing , a choppy , stiff wind that whipped the water into froth . It fluttered the skirts of [the two women]377-the two women and kept [them]377-the two women for a while engaged in adjusting , readjusting , tucking in , securing hair - pins and hat - pins . [A few persons]414-a few persons were sporting some distance away in [the water]188-the water . [The beach]175-the beach was very still of human sound at that hour . [The lady in black]417-the lady in black was reading [her]417-the lady in black morning devotions on [the porch of [a neighboring bath - house]419-a neighboring bath - house]418-the porch of a neighboring bath - house . [Two young lovers]420-two young lovers were exchanging [their]420-two young lovers hearts ' yearnings beneath [[the children]239-the children 's tent]422-the children 's tent , which [they]420-two young lovers had found unoccupied .

[Edna Pontellier]115-edna , casting [her]115-edna eyes about , had finally kept [them]423-them at rest upon [the sea]253-the sea . The day was clear and carried the gaze out as far as the blue sky went ; there were a few white clouds suspended idly over the horizon . [A lateen sail]425-a lateen sail was visible in [the direction of [Cat Island]7-cat island]426-the direction of cat island , and [others to the south]427-others to the south seemed almost motionless in the far distance .

" Of whom of what are [you]115-edna thinking ? " Likely as not it was Sunday , "[431-i] [she]431-i laughed ; " and [I]431-i was running away from prayers , from the Presbyterian service , read in a spirit of gloom by [[my]431-i father]1738-my father that chills [me]431-i yet to think of . "[431-i]

"[431-i]

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle laid [her]62-madame ratignolle hand over that of [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier , which was near [her]62-madame ratignolle . [She]62-madame ratignolle even stroked it a little , fondly , with the other hand , murmuring in an undertone , " _ Pauvre ch rie _ . "[62-madame ratignolle]

The action was at first a little confusing to [Edna]115-edna , but [she]115-edna soon lent [herself]115-edna readily to [the Creole]70-the creole 's gentle caress . [She]115-edna was not accustomed to an outward and spoken expression of affection , either in [herself]115-edna or in others . [She]115-edna and [[her]115-edna younger sister]433-her younger sister , [Janet]59-janet , had quarreled a good deal through force of unfortunate habit . [[Her]115-edna older sister]434-her older sister , [Margaret]71-margaret , was matronly and dignified , probably from having assumed matronly and housewifely responsibilities too early in life , [[their]435-they mother]436-their mother having died when [they]435-they were quite young . [Margaret]71-margaret was not effusive ; [she]71-margaret was practical . [Edna]115-edna had had [an occasional girl friend]437-an occasional girl friend , but whether accidentally or not , [they]435-they seemed to have been [all of one type the self - contained]438-all of one type the self - contained . [She]115-edna never realized that the reserve of [her]115-edna own character had much , perhaps everything , to do with this . [[Her]115-edna most intimate friend]439-her most intimate friend at [school]440-school had been one of rather exceptional intellectual gifts , who wrote fine - sounding essays , which [Edna]115-edna admired and strove to imitate ; and with [her]439-her most intimate friend [she]439-her most intimate friend talked and glowed over the English classics , and sometimes held religious and political controversies .

[Edna]115-edna often wondered at one propensity which sometimes had inwardly disturbed [her]115-edna without causing any outward show or manifestation on [her]115-edna part . At a very early age perhaps it was when [she]115-edna traversed [the ocean of waving grass]441-the ocean of waving grass [she]115-edna remembered that [she]115-edna had been passionately enamored of [a dignified and sad - eyed cavalry officer who visited [[her]115-edna father]211-her father in [Kentucky]8-kentucky]442-a dignified and sad - eyed cavalry officer who visited her father in kentucky . But [the cavalry officer]445-the cavalry officer melted imperceptibly out of [her]115-edna existence .

At another time [her]115-edna affections were deeply engaged by [a young gentleman who visited [a lady]447-a lady on [a neighboring plantation]448-a neighboring plantation]446-a young gentleman who visited a lady on a neighboring plantation . It was after [they]449-they went to [Mississippi]9-mississippi to live . [The young man]225-the young man was engaged to be married to [the young lady]451-the young lady , and [they]449-they sometimes called upon [Margaret]71-margaret , driving over of afternoons in [a buggy]452-a buggy . [Edna]115-edna was a little miss , just merging into [her]115-edna teens ; and the realization that [she]115-edna [herself]115-edna was nothing , nothing , nothing to [the engaged young man]453-the engaged young man was a bitter affliction to [her]115-edna . But [he]453-the engaged young man , too , went the way of dreams .

[She]115-edna was [a grown young woman]454-a grown young woman when [she]115-edna was overtaken by what [she]115-edna supposed to be the climax of [her]115-edna fate . It was when the face and figure of [a great tragedian]455-a great tragedian began to haunt [her]115-edna imagination and stir [her]115-edna senses . The persistence of the infatuation lent it an aspect of genuineness . The hopelessness of it colored it with the lofty tones of a great passion .

The picture of [the tragedian]456-the tragedian stood enframed upon [her]115-edna desk . [Any one]1731-any one may possess the portrait of [a tragedian]458-a tragedian without exciting suspicion or comment . ( This was a sinister reflection which [she]115-edna cherished . ) In the presence of [others]459-others [she]115-edna expressed admiration for [his]453-the engaged young man exalted gifts , as [she]115-edna handed the photograph around and dwelt upon the fidelity of the likeness . When alone [she]115-edna sometimes picked it up and kissed the cold glass passionately .

[Her]115-edna marriage to [L once Pontellier]57-l was purely an accident , in this respect resembling many other marriages which masquerade as the decrees of [Fate]73-fate . It was in the midst of [her]115-edna secret great passion that [she]115-edna met [him]453-the engaged young man . [He]453-the engaged young man fell in love , as [men]269-men are in the habit of doing , and pressed [his]453-the engaged young man suit with an earnestness and an ardor which left nothing to be desired . [He]453-the engaged young man pleased [her]115-edna ; [his]453-the engaged young man absolute devotion flattered [her]115-edna . [She]115-edna fancied there was a sympathy of thought and taste between [them]461-them , in which fancy [she]115-edna was mistaken . Add to this the violent opposition of [[her]115-edna father]211-her father and [[her]115-edna sister]463-her sister [Margaret]71-margaret to [her]115-edna marriage with [a Catholic]464-a catholic , and [we]465-we need seek no further for the motives which led [her]115-edna to accept [Monsieur Pontellier]74-monsieur pontellier for [[her]115-edna husband]186-her husband .

The acme of bliss , which would have been a marriage with [the tragedian]456-the tragedian , was not for [her]115-edna in [this world]468-this world . As [the devoted wife of [a man who worshiped [her]115-edna]470-a man who worshiped her]469-the devoted wife of a man who worshiped her , [she]115-edna felt [she]115-edna would take [her]115-edna place with a certain dignity in [the world of reality]471-the world of reality , closing the portals forever behind [her]115-edna upon the realm of romance and dreams .

But it was not long before [the tragedian]456-the tragedian had gone to join [the cavalry officer]445-the cavalry officer and [the engaged young man]453-the engaged young man and [a few others]475-a few others ; and [Edna]115-edna found [herself]115-edna face to face with the realities . [She]115-edna grew fond of [[her]115-edna husband]186-her husband , realizing with some unaccountable satisfaction that no trace of passion or excessive and fictitious warmth colored [her]115-edna affection , thereby threatening its dissolution .

[She]115-edna was fond of [[her]115-edna children]306-her children in an uneven , impulsive way . [She]115-edna would sometimes gather [them]306-her children passionately to [her]115-edna heart ; [she]115-edna would sometimes forget [them]306-her children . The year before [they]306-her children had spent part of the summer with [[their]306-her children grandmother]478-their grandmother [Pontellier]115-edna in [Iberville]10-iberville . Feeling secure regarding [their]306-her children happiness and welfare , [she]115-edna did not miss [them]306-her children except with an occasional intense longing . [Their]306-her children absence was a sort of relief , though [she]115-edna did not admit this , even to [herself]115-edna . [Edna]115-edna did not reveal so much as all this to [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle that summer day when [they]306-her children sat with faces turned to [the sea]253-the sea . "[496-she]

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle had spoken what [she]496-she believed to be the law and the gospel . [The young man]225-the young man shrugged [his]225-the young man shoulders impatiently .

" Oh ! well ! That is n't it , "[225-the young man] slamming [his]225-the young man hat down vehemently upon [his]225-the young man head . " [You]53-robert ought to feel that such things are not flattering to say to [a fellow]1752-a fellow . "[225-the young man]

" Should [our]1747-we whole intercourse consist of an exchange of compliments ? _ Ma foi ! _ "[225-the young man]

" It is n't pleasant to have [a woman]1753-a woman tell [you]53-robert "[225-the young man] [he]225-the young man went on , unheedingly , but breaking off suddenly : " Now if [I]225-the young man were like [Arobin]77-arobin [you]53-robert remember [Alc e Arobin]77-arobin and that story of [[the consul]1754-the consul 's wife]1755-the consul 's wife at [Biloxi]11-biloxi ? "[225-the young man] And [he]225-the young man related the story of [Alc e Arobin]77-arobin and [[the consul]1754-the consul 's wife]1755-the consul 's wife ; and another about the tenor of [the French Opera , who received letters which should never have been written]500-the french opera , who received letters which should never have been written ; and still other stories , grave and gay , till [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier and [her]52-mrs. pontellier possible propensity for taking [young men]501-young men seriously was apparently forgotten .

[Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle , when [they]502-they had regained [[her]62-madame ratignolle cottage]503-her cottage , went in to take the hour 's rest which [she]62-madame ratignolle considered helpful . Before leaving [her]62-madame ratignolle , [Robert]53-robert begged [her]62-madame ratignolle pardon for the impatience [he]53-robert called it rudeness with which [he]53-robert had received [her]62-madame ratignolle well - meant caution .

" [You]62-madame ratignolle made one mistake , Ad le , "[53-robert] [he]53-robert said , with a light smile ; " there is no earthly possibility of [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier ever taking [me]53-robert seriously . [You]62-madame ratignolle should have warned [me]53-robert against taking [myself]53-robert seriously . [Your]62-madame ratignolle advice might then have carried some weight and given [me]53-robert subject for some reflection . _ Au revoir _ . But [you]62-madame ratignolle look tired , "[53-robert] [he]53-robert added , solicitously . " Would [you]62-madame ratignolle like a cup of bouillon ? Shall [I]53-robert stir [you]62-madame ratignolle a toddy ? Let [me]53-robert mix [you]62-madame ratignolle a toddy with a drop of Angostura . "[53-robert]

[She]62-madame ratignolle acceded to the suggestion of bouillon , which was grateful and acceptable . [He]53-robert went [himself]53-robert to [the kitchen]504-the kitchen , which was [a building apart from [the cottages]159-the cottages and lying to the rear of [the house]157-the house]505-a building apart from the cottages and lying to the rear of the house . And [he]53-robert [himself]53-robert brought [her]62-madame ratignolle the golden - brown bouillon , in a dainty S vres cup , with a flaky cracker or two on the saucer .

[She]62-madame ratignolle thrust a bare , white arm from the curtain which shielded [her]62-madame ratignolle open door , and received the cup from [his]53-robert hands . [She]62-madame ratignolle told [him]53-robert [he]53-robert was a _ bon gar on _ , and [she]62-madame ratignolle meant it . [Robert]53-robert thanked [her]62-madame ratignolle and turned away toward " [the house]157-the house . "[53-robert]

[The lovers]489-the lovers were just entering [the grounds of [the _ pension _]510-the _ pension _]509-the grounds of the _ pension _ . [They]489-the lovers were leaning toward [each other]183-each other as the water - oaks bent from [the sea]253-the sea . There was not a particle of earth beneath [their]489-the lovers feet . [Their]489-the lovers heads might have been turned upside - down , so absolutely did [they]489-the lovers tread upon blue ether . [The lady in black]417-the lady in black , creeping behind [them]489-the lovers , looked a trifle paler and more jaded than usual . There was no sign of [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier and [the children]239-the children . [Robert]53-robert scanned the distance for any such apparition . [They]489-the lovers would doubtless remain away till the dinner hour . [The young man]225-the young man ascended to [[[his]225-the young man mother]208-his mother 's room]517-his mother 's room . [It]517-his mother 's room was situated at [the top of [the house]157-the house]518-the top of the house , made up of odd angles and a queer , sloping ceiling . Two broad dormer windows looked out toward [the Gulf]177-the gulf , and as far across [it]177-the gulf as [a man]521-a man 's eye might reach . The furnishings of [the room]522-the room were light , cool , and practical .

[Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun was busily engaged at the sewing - machine . [A little black girl]523-a little black girl sat on the floor , and with [her]523-a little black girl hands worked the treadle of the machine . [The Creole woman]321-the creole woman does not take any chances which may be avoided of imperiling [her]321-the creole woman health .

[Robert]53-robert went over and seated [himself]53-robert on the broad sill of one of the dormer windows . [He]53-robert took a book from [his]53-robert pocket and began energetically to read it , judging by the precision and frequency with which [he]53-robert turned the leaves . The sewing - machine made a resounding clatter in [the room]522-the room ; it was of a ponderous , by - gone make . In the lulls , [Robert]53-robert and [[his]53-robert mother]208-his mother exchanged bits of desultory conversation .

" Where is [Mrs. Pontellier]52-mrs. pontellier ? "[50-madame lebrun]

" Down at [the beach]175-the beach with [the children]239-the children . "[50-madame lebrun]

" [I]50-madame lebrun promised to lend [her]52-mrs. pontellier [the Goncourt]12-the goncourt . Do n't forget to take it down when [you]53-robert go ; it 's there on the bookshelf over the small table . "[50-madame lebrun] Clatter , clatter , clatter , bang ! for the next five or eight minutes .

" Where is [Victor]78-victor going with [the rockaway]258-the rockaway ? "[50-madame lebrun]

" [The rockaway]0-the rockaway ? [Victor]78-victor ? "[50-madame lebrun]

" Yes ; down there in front . [He]78-victor seems to be getting ready to drive away somewhere . "[50-madame lebrun]

" Call [him]78-victor . "[50-madame lebrun] Clatter , clatter !

[Robert]53-robert uttered a shrill , piercing whistle which might have been heard back at [the wharf]260-the wharf .

" [He]78-victor wo n't look up . "[50-madame lebrun]

[Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun flew to the window . [She]50-madame lebrun called " [Victor]78-victor ! "[50-madame lebrun] [She]50-madame lebrun waved a handkerchief and called again . [The young fellow below]528-the young fellow below got into [the vehicle]529-the vehicle and started the horse off at a gallop .

[Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun went back to the machine , crimson with annoyance . [Victor]78-victor was [the younger son]530-the younger son and brother a _ t te mont e _ , with a temper which invited violence and a will which [no ax could break]531-no ax could break .

" Whenever [you]50-madame lebrun say the word [I]530-the younger son 'm ready to thrash any amount of reason into [him]78-victor that [he]78-victor 's able to hold . "[530-the younger son]

" If [[your]50-madame lebrun father]1760-your father had only lived ! "[79-clatter] [Clatter]79-clatter , clatter , clatter , clatter , bang ! It was a fixed belief with [Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun that the conduct of [the universe]358-the universe and all things pertaining thereto would have been manifestly of a more intelligent and higher order had not [Monsieur Lebrun]80-monsieur lebrun been removed to other spheres during the early years of [their]533-their married life .

" What do [you]50-madame lebrun hear from [Montel]81-montel ? " Where did [you]50-madame lebrun say the Goncourt was ? "[79-clatter]

IX

Every light in [the hall]536-the hall was ablaze ; every lamp turned as high as it could be without smoking the chimney or threatening explosion . The lamps were fixed at intervals against the wall , encircling [the whole room]537-the whole room . [Some one]538-some one had gathered orange and lemon branches , and with these fashioned graceful festoons between . The dark green of the branches stood out and glistened against the white muslin curtains which draped the windows , and which puffed , floated , and flapped at the capricious will of a stiff breeze that swept up from [the Gulf]15-the gulf .

It was Saturday night a few weeks after the intimate conversation held between [Robert]53-robert and [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle on [their]539-their way from [the beach]175-the beach . An unusual number of [husbands]541-husbands , [fathers]542-fathers , and [friends]543-friends had come down to stay over Sunday ; and [they]539-their were being suitably entertained by [[their]539-their families]544-their families , with the material help of [Madame Lebrun]50-madame lebrun . The dining tables had all been removed to one end of [the hall]536-the hall , and the chairs ranged about in rows and in clusters . [Each little family group]546-each little family group had had [its]546-each little family group say and exchanged [its]546-each little family group domestic gossip earlier in the evening . There was now an apparent disposition to relax ; to widen the circle of confidences and give a more general tone to the conversation .

[Many of [the children]239-the children]547-many of the children had been permitted to sit up beyond [their]547-many of the children usual bedtime . [A small band of [them]547-many of the children]549-a small band of them were lying on [their]549-a small band of them stomachs on the floor looking at the colored sheets of the comic papers which [Mr. Pontellier]49-mr. pontellier had brought down . [The little Pontellier boys]287-the little pontellier boys were permitting [them]547-many of the children to do so , and making [their]547-many of the children authority felt .

Music , dancing , and a recitation or two were the entertainments furnished , or rather , offered . But there was nothing systematic about the programme , no appearance of prearrangement nor even premeditation .

At an early hour in the evening [the Farival twins]161-the farival twins were prevailed upon to play the piano . [They]161-the farival twins were [girls of fourteen , always clad in the Virgin]552-girls of fourteen , always clad in the virgin 's colors , blue and white , having been dedicated to [the Blessed Virgin]82-the blessed virgin at [their]161-the farival twins baptism . [They]161-the farival twins played a duet from " Zampa , "[161-the farival twins] and at the earnest solicitation of [every one present]553-every one present followed it with the overture to " [The Poet]1724-the poet and [the Peasant]1725-the peasant . "[554-the parrot outside the door]

" _ Allez vous - en ! Sapristi ! _ "[554-the parrot outside the door] shrieked [the parrot outside the door]554-the parrot outside the door . [He]554-the parrot outside the door was [the only being present who possessed sufficient candor to admit that [he]554-the parrot outside the door was not listening to these gracious performances for the first time that summer]555-the only being present who possessed sufficient candor to admit that he was not listening to these gracious performances for the first time that summer . [Old Monsieur Farival]64-old monsieur farival , [grandfather of [the twins]557-the twins]556-grandfather of the twins , grew indignant over the interruption , and insisted upon having the bird removed and consigned to [regions of darkness]558-regions of darkness . [Victor Lebrun]78-victor objected ; and [his]78-victor decrees were as immutable as those of [Fate]73-fate . [The parrot]559-the parrot fortunately offered no further interruption to the entertainment , the whole venom of [his]559-the parrot nature apparently having been cherished up and hurled against [the twins]557-the twins in that one impetuous outburst .

Later [a young brother]561-a young brother and [sister]562-sister gave recitations , which [every one present]553-every one present had heard many times at winter evening entertainments in [the city]261-the city .

[A little girl]565-a little girl performed a skirt dance in the center of the floor . [The mother]220-the mother played [her]220-the mother accompaniments and at the same time watched [[her]220-the mother daughter]567-her daughter with greedy admiration and nervous apprehension . [She]220-the mother need have had no apprehension . [The child]236-the child was [mistress of the situation]569-mistress of the situation . [She]236-the child had been properly dressed for the occasion in black tulle and black silk tights . [Her]236-the child little neck and arms were bare , and [her]236-the child hair , artificially crimped , stood out like fluffy black plumes over [her]236-the child head . [Her]236-the child poses were full of grace , and [her]236-the child little black - shod toes twinkled as they shot out and upward with a rapidity and suddenness which were bewildering .

But there was no reason why [every one]374-every one should not dance . [Madame Ratignolle]62-madame ratignolle could not , so it was [she]62-madame ratignolle who gaily consented to play for [the others]324-the others . [She]62-madame ratignolle played very well , keeping excellent waltz time and infusing an expression into the strains which was indeed inspiring . [She]62-madame ratignolle was keeping up [her]62-madame ratignolle music on account of [the children]239-the children , [she]62-madame ratignolle said ; because [she]62-madame ratignolle and [[her]62-madame ratignolle husband]186-her husband both considered it a means of brightening [the home]574-the home and making [it]574-the home attractive .

Almost [every one]374-every one danced but [the twins]557-the twins , who could not be induced to separate during the brief period when one or the other should be whirling around [the room]522-the room in the arms of [a man]521-a man . [They]557-the twins might have danced together , but [they]557-the twins did not think of it .

[The children]239-the children were sent to bed . [Some]580-some went submissively ; [others]459-others with shrieks and protests as [they]459-others were dragged away . [They]557-the twins had been permitted to sit up till after the ice - cream , which naturally marked the limit of human indulgence .

The ice - cream was passed around with cake gold and silver cake arranged on platters in alternate slices ; it had been made and frozen during the afternoon back of [the kitchen]504-the kitchen by [two black women]583-two black women , under the supervision of [Victor]78-victor . It was pronounced a great success excellent if it had only contained a little less vanilla or a little more sugar , if it had been frozen a degree harder , and if the salt might have been kept out of portions of it . [Victor]78-victor was proud of [his]78-victor achievement , and went about recommending it and urging [every one]374-every one to partake of it to excess .
